dialogue.raw_text: It's nothin' compared to what you could be makin' on the Big Con. You're wastin' your time workin' street marks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey look.  You think I'm gonna run out on ya or somethin'?  Just cause we hit it big.  Luther, I owe you everything.  If you hadn't taught me con, I wouldn't know nothin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little embarrassed) Aw hell, you sound like some goddamn sucker.  You know everything I know.  You got nothin' more to learn from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you played the Big Con.  You said it was nothin'.  A game for flakes and mama's boys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I'm tellin' ya now, you're a fool if you don't get into it.  A bigger fool than I was. (pause, holding up the money) I been lookin' for this one all my life, Johnny.  Now I got a chance to step out at the top.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a long silence) What the hell you gonna do with yourself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aw, I got a brother down in K.C., runs a freight outlet.  I can go halfsies with 'em!  It ain't too exciting, but it's mostly legal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Straighten up, kid.  I wouldn't turn ya out if ya weren't ready. (flipping Hooker a piece of paper) I got a guy named Henry Gondorff I want you to look up.  There ain't a better insideman alive.  He'll teach ya everything ya gotta know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll take a cut of what I make, won't ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm out, Johnny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If that's the way you want it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the way I want it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's late at night now.  Hooker and Eirie wander along the street together, not really ready to go home, but with no other ideas either.  Hooker, obviously preoccupied, idly strikes a match on a street lamp as he passes and lets it burn out.  He does this several times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk on a few more feet, when suddenly a police car pulls up alongside them and two men jump out.  The first, a uniformed policeman, grabs Eirie around the neck. Hooker makes a break for it, but the second Figure, a burly detective named Snyder, tackles him in the middle of the street, drags him back into the alley and plasters him up against a brick wall.  The two have met before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snyder gives Hooker a swift knee in the thigh and follows it with an elbow across the head.  Hooker flies into a row of boxes and garbage cans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bang.  Snyder, infuriated by Hooker's irreverence, slams him to the ground again.  The policeman is no longer holding Eirie but is almost daring him to make a move.  Eirie wants to go to Hooker's aid, but he knows the policeman will beat him to a pulp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snyder lets go.  Hooker sinks back against the wall.  He says nothing; he's waiting for the price.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker is beat and he knows it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches into his coat, pulls out a stack of bills and counts out $2000 to Snyder.  Eirie looks on in amazement; he didn't think Hooker had it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snyder and his policeman friend get in their car and start down the street.  Hooker and Eirie walk nonchalantly in the other direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snyder and his partner disappear around a corner.  Hooker suddenly takes off like a shot.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How do you like that Coleman, huh? After three years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aw come on, it was the only thing to do.  He knew he was holdin' ya back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We were partners.  If it weren't for Luther I'd still be hustlin' pinball down at Gianelli's.  I don't need anything more than I got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ain't gonna have nothin' if you don't lay off them games of chance. There's a depression on ya know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's always a depression on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you saved a little, you wouldn't have to grift so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like griftin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could buy yourself some things. Clothes, or a nice car...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't look any good in clothes and I don't know how to drive. What else ya got to sell, Eirie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi there, Snyder.  Things a little slow down at the Bunco Department tonight, eh?  Somebody lose the dominoes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You scored blood money today, Hooker.  You need a friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (knocking Snyder's hand away) Aw, find yourself a shoplifter to roll.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting up slowly) You got the wrong guy, pal.  I been home with the flu all day. (rising to a fuller height) You can stake out my toilet if you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling Hooker out of the heap and smashing him against the wall again) I'll tell ya what you did, smart boy.  You tied into a loaded mark on 47th across from Maxies.  You and Coleman played the switch for him and blew him off to a cab on
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: th.  If he hadn't been a numbers runner for Doyle Lonnegan, it woulda been perfect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled by the information) You're crazy.  I'm not stupid enough to play for rackets money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not intentionally maybe, but that don't make no difference to Lonnegan. He'll swat you like any fly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll square it with the fixer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody can buy you a prayer, if I put the finger on ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I figure your end of the score was at least 3 gees.  I want 2 no matter what it was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lying) My end was only one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not taking the fake) Then you'll have to come up with another grand somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pocketing the money and motioning his partner to put his gun away) You're a smart egg, Hooker.  No use dyin' for 2 grand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you blew all your money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did.  That stuff I gave him was counterfeit.  They'll pinch him the first place he tries to spend it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He runs into a drugstore and goes to the phone booth. There's already a woman in it.  Hooker rips open the door and throws her out.  Hurriedly, he begins to dial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker, still getting no answer, slams the phone down and blasts out of the booth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (standing outside the booth) What the hell you gonna do when Snyder rushes his finger right to Lonnegan?  You're committin' suicide, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (waiting for the ring) Aw Christ, it doesn't make no difference now.  If Snyder knows about it so does everybody else. He never gets anything first...Damn, there's no answer at Luther's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to me, Hooker.  What ever you do, don't go back to your place tonight, don't go anyplace you usually go, ya hear me?  Get outa town or somethin', but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eirie chases him frantically, calling him to come back, but he's giving away too many years and there's no stopping Hooker at this point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SHOTS OF HOOKER Pumping down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker races into Luther's brownstone, charges up to the third floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker runs up through a small group of people on the stairs. He bursts into Luther's room, the door of which is already open.  The room shows signs of a struggle, a turned-over chair, a broken lamp, but there is no Coleman.  Hooker goes slowly to the window.  He looks down into the courtyard and then suddenly sprints back out the door.  As we hear him scrambling down the stairs, the camera dollies to the window and looks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There on the concrete below, face down, is the body of Luther Coleman.  Hooker races out to it and kneels down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the distance, sirens are heard.  Heads are out of the windows and some people are starting to gather in the courtyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sirens are close now, and Hooker tears himself away from Luther and runs.  The others gather to look at the body.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking the body) C'mon Luther, get up.  You gotta get up, Luther.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn you, Luther, will you get up? (pounding on the body) I'm not waitin' for you, Luther. I'm not waitin' anymore.  Get up, you son of a bitch.  Goddamn you, Luther, goddamn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We open on Hooker sleeping in some remote corner of the station, covered with newspapers for warmth, and barely distinguishable from the clutter of junk surrounding him.  A station security officer, on his morning sweep, wanders by and delivers a terrific blow to the soles of Hooker's feet with a nightstick.  Hooker jolts awake with a cry of pain, as the officer diffidently moves on toward another sleeping victim. Tired and sore from his night in the station, Hooker struggles to his feet and attempts to take stock of the situation.  He tries to smooth the wrinkles out of his suit, but it's futile.  A quick check of his wallet finds it as empty as he'd remembered it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - GIFT SHOP - DAY Hooker walks in and goes to the toy section.  He looks through several small novelties, till he finds what he's looking for -- a little tin replica of a policeman's badge. He looks around for station detectives, and seeing none, slips the badge into his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WASHROOM - DAY Hooker rinses out his mouth, towels off his face and slicks his hair back with water.  It's a drop in the bucket, but it seems to revitalize him a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HALLWAY - DAY We see Hooker removing a sign from a door, but the angle prohibits us from reading it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drops the sign in a waste can and walks out into the crowded passenger lobby.  After scanning the area carefully for a minute, he goes up to a conservative young business man, who's busy reading the schedule board.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Businessman is totally shamed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man goes off down the hall, more than grateful to be given a break like this.  Hooker heads for the "back".  We follow the Man down the hall to the unmarked door.  He strides on through to find himself face to face with a wall of busily flushing urinals.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (flashing open his wallet to reveal the little tin badge and then closing it again quickly) Excuse me, sir.  Treasury Dept... I'd like to ask you a few questions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flustered) What for?  I haven't done anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't doubt that, but there's a counterfeiting operation passing bad money in the station.  Have you made any purchases here today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reluctantly) Yes, a ticket to Chicago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I'm afraid we'll have to impound your money until we're sure that it's all good.  Can I see your wallet and your ticket, please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (handing them over) But I got a train to make.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking out the money and returning the wallet) It'll only take 20 minutes or so. You can pick it up at the window down the hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what about all these other people?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blowing up) We'll get 'em!  Give us a chance. I'm not the only agent in here, ya know.  We go around advertising ourselves, how many counterfeiters do you think we'd catch, huh? (pointing to his suit) You think I'm wearin' this rag here 'cause I like it?  Christ, everybody thinks life's a holiday or somethin' when you got a badge. (pouring it on) I been here since three this morning, Charlie, and I never knew there was so much ugliness in people.  You try to help 'em and they spit on you.  I shoulda let ya go and gotten yourself arrested for passin' false notes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, really I am, but my train leaves in ten minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, I'll give ya a break. (pointing to a hall) Down that hall there, there's an unmarked door on the left.  Go on in there and wait at the window. I'll take this... (he holds up the money) ...in the back and run it through right away.  We'll have you outta there in a couple minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.  You don't know how much I appreciate this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a little wave) Think nothin' of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - HOOKER Boarding the 8:10 for Chicago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Man wandering up and down the hall, wondering how he could have missed that room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The street runs along side an elevated train track.  We pick up Hooker coming down the street, eating a hot dog he bought with the money he just earned in the train station. He appears to be looking for an address, referring every now and then to the piece of paper Luther gave him the night before.  Finally he stops in front of an old three-story building which contains a carousel on the bottom 2 floors and what appear to be apartments on the third floor.  He peers inside the big, sliding glass doors and seeing no sign of life, goes around to the side to look for a way in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: year-old woman, Billie, appears in her bathrobe on the second floor landing and descends the stairs to get the morning paper.  She's eating an apple.  Although she has just gotten up and looks it, she has the presence of one who is probably quite striking at other hours.  The sight of Hooker fazes her not at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billie stops and comes back down the stairs.  It's the first time she's stopped chewing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes to a side door and unlocks it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker's not quite sure what that means, but there's something about Billie that makes him know that you don't ask.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, I'm looking for a guy named Henry Gondorff.  You know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (starting back up the stairs) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Luther Coleman sent me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (checking him out) You Hooker?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you say so.  I thought maybe you was a copper or somethin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the room in the back.  He wasn't expecting you so soon though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hooker walks past the now motionless carousel to the room in the back and knocks on the door.  No answer.  He gives the door a little push and it swings open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room inside if small and cluttered, consisting of a bed, a sink, and a bathroom, all covered by a layer of books, dirty clothes and beer bottles.  Draped over a chair, fully dressed, but completely passed out is the one and only Henry Gondorff.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) The great Henry Gondorff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Water blasting out of the fixture.  We see Gondorff, still fully clothed, sitting in the bottom of the shower, the spray streaming off his face.  An imposing figure, with deep set eyes and full beard, he just sits there stoically, looking like a soggy lumberjack.  Hooker, sitting on the floor between the toilet and the sink, watches listlessly. Finally -- GONDORFF Turn the goddamn thing off, will ya.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker makes no move to get up.  Gondorff struggles to his knees, turns off the water, and slumps back against the wall. The two men just look past each other a second.  Down in the bottom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff wipes his face with his hand.  His mood softens a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker's disappointment is obvious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker nods, unconvinced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We go to Hooker.  He hadn't thought of that.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You sober?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can talk, can't I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Glad to meet ya, kid.  You're a real horse's ass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, Luther said you could teach me something.  I already know how to drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) I'm sorry about Luther.  He was the best street worker I ever saw.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He had you down as a big-timer. What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aw, I conned a Senator from Florida on a stocks deal.  A real lop-ear. He thought he was gonna take over General Electric.  Some Chantoozie woke him up, though, and he put the feds on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you blew it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) Luther didn't tell me you had a big mouth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He didn't tell me you was a fuck- up, either. (Gondorff looks at him coldly) You played the Big Con since then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I lammed it around for a while while things cooled off.  Philly, Denver, Baltimore, nuthin' towns.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But don't kid yourself, friend, I still know how.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting up from the floor and emptying the water out of his pockets) You gonna stay for breakfast, or do you already know how to eat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tired) I picked something up on the way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sensing something) Lonnegan after you, too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.  Haven't seen anybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You never do, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan, in plus fours and argyles sits on a bench as other members of his foursome tee off.  Floyd comes up to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan regards Floyd patiently and then pats the bench beside him.  Floyd sits gingerly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We cut to one of Lonnegan's foursome, a short, squat little Irishman in a red sweater.  He was a good-time, friendly manner and a winning Irish smile.  We like him immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan is called to the tee by one of his foursome.  He exchanges a friendly smile with McCoy and belts the ball down the fairway.
direction.name: direction

location: A BEAUTIFUL OLD COLONIAL COUNTRY CLUB
result.heading: EXT.

dialogue.raw_text: We got word from Chicago.  They got one of the grifters last night. The nigger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about the other one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're still looking for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's got the contract?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Combs gave it to Reilly and Cole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hackers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They staked out the other guy's place last night, but he never showed.  They figure maybe he skipped town.  You wanna follow 'em up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see the guy in the red sweater over there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Name's Danny McCoy.  No Neck McCoy we called him.  Runs a few protection rackets for Carnello while he's waiting for something bigger to come along.  Me and Danny been friends since we were six. Take a good look at that face, Floyd, cause if he ever finds out we let one lousy grifter beat us, you'll have to kill him and every other hood in Chicago who'd like to do the same thing.  You understand what I'm sayin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good lad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gondorff, dried off now and in a new set of clothes, is pulling up the shades of the large facing windows of the carousel building.  The morning light pours in, illuminating fully for the first time the ornate merry-go-round and its massive oaken horses.  Hooker watches him go about his business.  Billie calls down from the mezzanine which surrounds the carousel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff waves okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff walks around on the carousel, checking straps, bearing and poles.  Hooker follows him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff just sits tight and waits for him to cool off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the right answer. Gondorff didn't know it himself until now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker nods.  Gondorff switches on the carousel and steps back to admire his handiwork.  The carousel makes a grinding sound, does a few lurches and stops cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Music begins and we are into a short:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You feeling all right this morning, Henry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, Billie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mind opening the round a little early today?  We got some business coming in before hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Hooker) Great little countess, that Billie. Runs a good house up there, too. One of the few left that Luciano doesn't own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting impatient) Gondorff, you gonna teach me the Big Con or not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on his back, checking underneath one of the horses) You didn't act much like you wanted to learn it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanna play for Lonnegan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting up) You know anything about him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exploding) Yeh, he croaked Luther.  What else do I gotta know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (waving Gondorff off, embarrassed at his own outburst) Aw right, he runs the numbers outta the south side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going over to start the machinery) And a packing company, a chain of Savings and Loans and half the politicians in Chicago and New York. There ain't a fix in the world gonna cool him out if he blows on ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take him anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whirling on him) Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (like steel) 'Cause I don't know enough about killin' to kill him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't do it alone, ya know.  It takes a mob of guys like you and enough money to make 'em look good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll get by without 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't like playin' winos on the street.  You gotta do more than outrun the guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incensed) I never played for winos.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going right on, ignoring Hooker's remark) You gotta keep Lonnegan's con, even after you spent his money.  And no matter how much you take from his, he'll get more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're sacred of 'em, aren't ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right down to my socks, turkey.  If I'da been half as scared a that lop-ear, I wouldn't a fallen asleep on 'em.  Lonnegan might kill me, but at least he won't bore me to death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you'll do it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I can find a mob that'll risk it. But no matter what happens, I don't want you comin' back to me halfway through and sayin' it's not enough... cause it's all you got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Detailing the arrival of the others three members of Gondorff's "mob." Throughout, Gondorff wears the fedora hat which is his trademark.  We begin with -- A tall, good-looking man, Kid Twist, making his way through the railway station.  Impeccably dressed and carrying a small suitcase, he combs the terrain carefully with his eyes. Finally he catches a glimpse of the thing he's been looking for.  It's Gondorff, standing by a newsstand.  Gondorff makes a quick snubbing motion on his nose as if flicking off a gnat.  This is known among con men as the "office." Twist returns the sign with a barely discernible smile as he walks on by.  Con men rarely acknowledge each other openly in public, but it's obvious that these two are glad to see each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker in, having his hair cut and his nails manicured. Gondorff gives instructions to the barber.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker is modeling a new suit in front of a mirror.  He doesn't look too pleased, but Gondorff peels out a bankroll anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pair of white spats stepping off a bus.  We follow them into a:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where we tilt up to reveal J.J. Singleton, the most flamboyant of the bunch.  On his way to the check-in desk, he silently exchanges the "office" with Gondorff, who is sitting on a lounge reading the paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker being shown into a small apartment room by an old woman.  It consists of a bed, a table and a sink.  Hooker nods his acceptance to the woman and gives her a bill.  He takes another look around the room and decides to go out somewhere, but first he wedges a small piece of paper between the door and the jamb, about an inch off the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hold on a slight, bespectacled teller, Eddie Niles, in the process of counting a large deposit.  Niles is all business; if he's ever smiled, no one knows about it.  He glances up for a second and sees Gondorff "officing" him from across the bank.  Without a word he shoves the money he's been counting back into the hands of a startled customer, abruptly closes up his window, flips his identification tag on the manager's desk and walks out of the bank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This room has obviously been relegated to the status of the storage room.  It contains the water heater, mops and brooms, old bed springs, etc.  In the middle of the room a space has been cleared for a table, around which are seated Hooker, Gondorff, Niles, Singleton and Twist.  Gondorff is in his T-shirt, but still wears his hat.  Kid Twist is in a suit as usual.  The room is illuminated by a single bare bulb hanging from the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We recognize Riley and Cole as the two guys who got into Mottola's cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We go to Hooker.  He's real grateful.  Billie, wearing an evening dress, enters the room and begins gathering up the empty beer mugs on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker nods, but we know he hasn't really got that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billie has finished  gathering the mugs, and leaves the room with them.  We follow her down the hall and into the:
direction.name: direction

location: AN UPSTAIRS ROOM OF THE CAROUSEL BUILDING
result.heading: INT.

dialogue.raw_text: (showing Hooker photographs of three men) These are Combs' favorite torpedoes. Riley and Cole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They do most of the small jobs, but Lonnegan might not wanna use 'em on you 'cause they're kinda messy.  No class.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got reason to believe Riley was the guy who hit Luther.  But if you see either one of these two, find yourself a crowd, or take 'em someplace you know you can handle 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But most of all let us know.  If they got a hit on you, we gotta fold up the con.  You're too exposed.  You got that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sure it'll be one of these two?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.  They're just the only ones we know of.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carousel music filters up from the arcade below.  The room has a bar along one wall and the rest of the space is taken up by tables and couches.  It's a comfortable place, but not opulent.  Some of the girls sit patiently on the couches, others play canasta at the tables.  Most of the men are at the bar, fortifying themselves for the task at hand.  Billie comes over to the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Danny goes to fill the mugs, Billie's eyes fix on a man at the end of the bar. We move to reveal Snyder, intently scanning the room, as if he'd lost a dancing partner in the crush.  Not finding what he wants, he comes down the bar to Billie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billie grabs a bottle of beer, pours some in a shot glass and pushes it over to Snyder.  He ignores the gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We go to Billie.  She knew that when he came in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the bartender) Set me up five more beers, will ya Danny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You the owner here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flipping out his badge) Lieutenant Snyder.  Bunco.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Joliet badge, Snyder.  Don't cut much up here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to ignore her remark) I'm lookin' for a guy on the lam from a counterfeiting rap.  Thought he mighta come in here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't think so.  I know everybody in the place and I always bounce the lamsters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right if I look around your lobby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but you're welcome to a free beer before you go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with controlled force) I don't really need your permission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The discussion continues.  Hooker, a bit out of his depth here, listens and stays silent.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lonnegan's a fast egg, Henry.  He's not gonna sit still for a standard play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody'll sit still for somethin'. What did ya find out about the train, Eddie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's been taking the 8:10 Century Limited outa New York on Friday and getting in here early Saturday morning.  He usually stays a day to check on his policy operations, and then flies back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wonder why he doesn't fly both ways.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The porters say he runs a braced card game in one of the cars.  $100 minimum, straight poker.  Last time he pulled in here ten grand heavier than he left New York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fancies himself a gambler, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lotta plungers ride that train just to play him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (breaking into a smile) See J.J., he's slowly down already.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Snyder has completed his inspection of the "lobby" and found nothing.  Danny, meanwhile, has set up the five beers on a tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snyder is stopped cold.  He calls after her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Which way are the rooms?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who told ya this guy was in here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody.  I just know what kinda women he likes.  I'm gonna check all the joyhouses till I find him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I could help ya if ya told me his name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I'll keep that to myself. Which way are the rooms?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right through there.  But I wouldn't go in there if I were you. (picks up the tray)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snidely) What are ya gonna do, call the cops?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't have to.  You'll be bustin' in on the Chief of Police just up the hall. (she exits with the drinks)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep your nose clean, lady.  He can't spend all his time here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Billie comes over to Gondorff and whispers in his ear, while the others talk.  His eyes flick momentarily to Hooker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff has nodded to Billie and now rejoins the conversation.  She serves the others beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Hooker.  There is a challenge in their book. Gondorff smiles broadly, then casually, to them all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We go around the table.  No reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hitches up Billie's skirt, and puts the bill in her garter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billie smiles and leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think we ought to play him on the Rag.  It's the tightest game we got, and it's not all over the papers yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No good, J.J.  You're not gonna con stocks to a banker.  Lonnegan's too smart for that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to do, con the payoff to a gambler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twist is right.  It won't work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll use the wire.  Never known a gambler who wouldn't like to beat the ponies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The wire is ten years outa date.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why he won't know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure I know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll give him the hook on the train, and play him here.  You think I can get in that poker game, Eddie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All you gotta do is show up with some money and look like a fool.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I also gotta win.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By the way, any of you guys been passing off any green goods lately?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Billie, if that Dick comes in again, stall him till I can get a look at him.  And let me pay ya for these beers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talking about?  It's on the house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling out a $5 bill) Naw, I want ya to have this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't look at it till ya go to bed though or it'll turn to paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She walks halfway down the hall and stops.  She can't wait. Lifting up her skirt, she finds that the five has indeed turned to paper.  As she breaks into laughter and continues on down the hall, we:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually little more than a service area between two apartment buildings.  Niles, Kid Twist, and a middle-aged black man, named Benny Garfield, enter the alley with an old man and follow him down a stairwell to a subterranean basement.  A faded sign above the door says Stenner's Billiards.  We follow them inside to a:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An office comes off it at one end.  Judging from the fluorescent lights overhead and the scattered cue racks which still hang tenuously on the walls, the place, indeed, used to be a pool hall.  Niles and Garfield go all the way to the back, while Twist stays near the front with the old man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Garfield thinks it over a little.  He's taking another look at the place.  We go to Twist and the old man by the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We go back to Niles and Garfield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twist has rejoined them by now.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Looks all right.  It's big enough and off the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.  This is kinda short notice.  I'm not sure we can get it all done by Saturday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got to.  Gondorff's ridin' the mark in from New York on the Century.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll take it. (pointing through the door) You manage the building at the end of the alley?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with pride) For fifteen years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll need a room over there that faces this way.  How much a week?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only rents by the month.  Two hundred and fifty for the two of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling out his wallet) This is the last time I expect to see you down here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (watching the bills being counted into his hand) Never heard of the place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Been a while since I stocked a wire store.  Not many mobs playing that anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All we need is the bookie setup for now.  We'll worry about the telegraph office later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, I'll rent ya everything I got in the warehouse for two grand.  That'll give ya phones, cages, blackboards and ticker gear. You supply the guys to move 'em. If you want a counter and bar, that's another grand.  I don't know where the hell I'm gonna get 'em though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, you can do better than that. We ain't no heel grifters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want the stuff tomorrow or don't ya?  It's gonna take hours just to clean it up. (pause) Besides, Gondorff's still a hot item.  Where am I gonna be if he gets hit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just give us what ya can, Benny. We'll send a truck down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Garfield) You wanna work flat rate or percentage?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's the mark?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doyle Lonnegan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Flat rate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We pick up Doyle Lonnegan, accompanied by two bodyguards and Floyd, making his way through the station.  He stops at a cigar counter to buy some cigarettes, and we reveal Gondorff and Hooker sitting on their suitcases on the other side of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker looks and finally spots him in the crowd.  We go back to Lonnegan, as he moves off from the cigar counter, toward his train.  Hooker watches him with the intensity of one gazing on a religious object.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (eyes fixed on Lonnegan) Guy in the blue pinstripe and grey fedora.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not as tough as he'd like to think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (picking up his suitcase) Neither are we.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan and his retainers getting on the train.  Two cars down the line, we see Hooker and Gondorff boarding also.  On his way in, Gordorff takes the conductor aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff flashes a $50 bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff pulls out another fifty.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I hear there's a friendly poker game on this train tonight.  You know anything about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think you could get me in that game?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.  There's usually a waiting list.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (loosening up a bit) That'll get you first alternate, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking the money) I'll see what I can do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kid Twist enters and threads his way through the maze of tables to a door at the back of the building.  A large bull of a man is stationed there, obviously to discourage those who don't have credentials to enter.  Twist is not such a man.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (going right on through) How ya doin', Lacey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (innocently pleased for one so menacing) Good to see ya again, Twist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Inside is another room, this one much better lit than the outer one.  There are only three tables in here, around which are seated the elite of the Con World.  Twist is enthusiastically greeted by Duke Boudreau, a large, rotund man whose stylish dress and authoritative manner mark him as a powerful figure in this group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two men sit down together, apart from the others.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Twist!  When did you get back in town?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coupla days ago.  I'm workin' a big one with Gondorff on the North Side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen Duke, we're setting up a wire store.  I need a twenty man boost right away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got twenty or so in here tonight. Take your pick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These guys have gotta be the quill, Duky.  We can't afford to rank the joint.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to one of his assistants) Get me the sheet, Jake.  Let's see who's in town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A silhouetted figure appears in the entrance doorway.  The word "chill" races from table to table and the place falls still.  The bartender pushes a button behind the bar and a buzzer goes off in the back room.  Boudreau gets up from his table and opens a small viewing port in the door. The silhouetted figure is now walking slowly past the silent tables.  It's Snyder and he's checking out every face in the place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snyder walks all the way to the back, and then retraces his route.  About halfway back, he stops at one of the tables, recognizing a grifter he knows.  It's the Eirie Kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snyder, in no mood for jokes, grabs Eirie by the hair and slams his face into the table.  Eirie just stays there; he knows it doesn't pay to assault a detective.  Twist is watching all this intently from the viewing port.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eirie raises his head slowly, but says nothing.  There is a slight trickle of blood from his nose.  Snyder turns and walks slowly out of the bar.  When he is a safe distance down the street, the chatter and drinking resume.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE OUTER PART OF THE BAR AGAIN

dialogue.raw_text: Twist, you know this guy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking a look through the viewing port) No.  Never saw him before.  He's a dick, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Snyder.  What are you doin' up here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm on vacation.  You seen your friend lately?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, he packed it in and enrolled in detective school.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see him, you tell him to pay his debts before I get him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Twist gives an all clear signal and returns to the table where he and Boudreau were talking.  Boudreau reads from a list of names.  Twist listens with a certain preoccupation. He's still thinking about the little confrontation he just witnessed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Paltrow, Sterling, Furey, and the Big Alabama are in from New Orleans. Fiskin and the Boone Kid from Denver, and Phillips, Barnett and Limehouse Chappie from New York. Those and the guys outside should give ya 30 or so to choose from.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good, have 'em down at Stenner's old Pool Hall before 3:00.  We're gonna run through the route tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Twist, but you know if this blows up, I can't do ya no good downtown.  Gondorff is Federal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry about it, pal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ripping through an open stretch between New York and Chicago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Singleton is walking down a passageway and stops at a door and goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff is rapidly shuffling cards to four empty places. He is alone.  He looks up as Singleton enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Singleton slips out as Gondorff unpeels the packs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, I think so.  I gave the kay- ducer a C-note.  You find out the deck?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He usually plays with a Royal or a Cadenza. (handing him two sealed decks) I got you one of each.  He likes to cold deck low, 8's or 9's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice work, J.J.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We pick up Lonnegan coming out of his compartment, flanked by only one bodyguard and Floyd.  He starts through the passenger section toward the compartment where the poker game will be held.  Suddenly a drunken woman comes staggering around the corner and bumps into him. They grapple a moment and Lonnegan pushes her away in disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan ignores her and proceeds down the passageway.  As the woman proceeds in the other direction between passengers, we see it is Billie.  She drops something on a seat beside a passenger.  A hand reaches to pick it up.  It is Lonnegan's wallet and it is Hooker who picks it up. Hooker waits a moment, then stands and goes in the direction Lonnegan has taken.  He passes by the open door to the card room, hesitating only slightly to hear the greetings exchanged inside before the door is shut.  Then he continues on into the next car.  He turns into Gondorff's compartment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sloppy drunk) Keep your mitts off me, ya big lug. If I'da wanted you handlin' me I woulda asked ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gondorff is still practicing.  He looks up as Hooker enters and tosses him the wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff nods, takes the money out, counts it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes out his own wallet and puts the money in it, and tosses the empty wallet back to Hooker, and resumes his shuffling and dealing.  Hooker sits back silently and watches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he deals, on the second pass he attempts to cut from the bottom, muffs it completely and sprays half the deck on the table.  Hooker regards him steadily as he gathers them back up.  Gondorff finally meets his gaze.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She got him clean.  He hasn't missed it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fifteen grand.  Looks like he's expecting a big night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's waitin' for you in the card room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let him wait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just worry about your end, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we ever get to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A specially outfitted compartment with a table and chairs in the middle and leather cushions around the outside for kibitzers.  Lonnegan and 3 other players are already there and seated.  They're getting slightly impatient.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the Conductor) Where the hell is this guy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.  He said he'd be here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gondorff is standing in front of the mirror dressing.  He grabs up a clean white shirt and rumples it up in his hands. He then picks up a half-full bottle of bourbon.  Hooker gives him a disapproving look.  Gondorff smiles and pats some on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody's itchy now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Conductor hands him a sealed deck.  As he begins to open it, Gordoff comes into the room, coatless, rumpled, unshaven and looking slightly tipsy.  The others at the table, all men of high school or financial standing, are somewhat put off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This bit of grossness does little to improve his image.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff nods and takes a seat, none too gracefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He begins to deal, obviously not pleased that his evening seems to be peopled with drunks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, let's start without him. Mr. Clemens, give me the cards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry I'm late boys.  I was takin' a crap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (making the introductions; referring first to Gondorff) Mr. Shaw is a bookmaker from Chicago.  Mr. Shaw, meet Mr. Clayton from Pittsburgh, Mr. Jameson, Chicago, Mr. Lonnegan, New York and Mr. Lombard, Philadelphia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Straight poker, gentlemen.  100 dollar minimum, table stakes.  We assume you're good for your debts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shuffling the cards) Mr. Shaw, we usually require a tie at this table.  If you don't have one, we can get ya one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, that'd be real nice of ya, Mr. Lonneman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated) Lonnegan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A truck is now parked at the end of the alley, and several workmen are busy unloading it.  One group carries a large blackboard; others have boxes of glasses, ash tray stands, furniture, etc.  Take several cuts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now a blaze of activity.  We take several cuts of workmen papering the walls, tacking down carpet, putting in new light fixtures, painting signs, all under the supervision of Niles.  From now on, we will refer to the pool hall as the store. Back in the office, Kid Twist is "interviewing" one by one, a group of con men lined up outside the office door.  A gray-haired old buzzard, Curly Jackson, approaches the table which is serving Twist as a desk.  Curly is practically in rags and has several days growth on his face.  He wears a little beret which he takes off to address Twist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twist is taken with the man, despite his appearance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Name's Curly Jackson.  I worked for Gad Bryan outa Baltimore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever played the Wire, Curly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Used to rope for it long ago.  I can shill, mark board, anything you want.  I don't run with riffraff and I only drink on weekends. (affecting an English accent) Me specialty is an Englishman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, Curly, you're in.  We got a rack of suits over there. Get yourself a nice tweed one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exiting) That's all right.  I got all my own stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gondorff and Lonnegan have most of the chips.  Lonnegan is slightly ahead.  Gondorff has made a token attempt to wear the provided tie, having tied it in a knot around his neck, but not having bothered to put it under his collar.  He has a shot glass and a bottle next to him, from which he has been drinking heavily.  He and Lonnegan are the only ones left in this hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan lays down his hand, a solid two pair.  Gondoroff turns out three tens.  Lonnegan is beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan burns, and the "boys" have no comment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (throwing chips in) Raise 500.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (likewise) See ya and raise three.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (more chips) See and raise five.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five and call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tough luck, Lonnihan, but that's what you get for playin' with your head up your ass.  Couple more like that and we can all go to bed early, huh boys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The work is still progressing.  We see two workmen installing a ticket tape machine in a secluded area of the store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We go to Kid Twist, still conducting interviews in the office.  A young, rather sullen man, Buck Duff, steps to the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Duff stands there a second and then slouches away from the table.  He stops however, by the door.  The next man up is the Eirie Kid.  Twist knows he's seen him somewhere before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twist waits for more, but it's not coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eirie nods a reluctant "yes."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eirie is so happy, he can barely blurt out a thank you. Buck Duff, enraged that Twist would hire a total amateur, turns in disgust and strides vengefully out of the store.

location: AN OLD DRUGSTORE ACROSS FROM THE ALLEY
result.heading: INT.

direction.raw_text: The place is full of people, although we avoid long shot so as not to give away the room as a whole yet.  Instead, we concentrate on the tense, waiting faces of some of the more familiar people: Gondorff and Niles in tuxedos behind a barred cashier's area. Gondorff mutilates a piece of gum in his mouth.  Niles just stares out into space cracking his knuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boardmarker walking nervously back and forth in front of his odds board, checking every letter and number.  He stops to cross a T on one of the horses' names.  It was already crossed, but he does it again anyway. Billie and Singleton, in an area hidden from the rest of the room, watching the print-out on the ticker machine.  The clicking of the ticker is the only sound we hear in the store. Curly Jackson in front of a mirror, pasting a fake Van Dyke on his chin to go with his tweed suit and monocle. A couple of Billie's girls adjusting their waitress outfits and primping their hair.  Each has a tray full of drinks beside her. The Eirie Kid silently retracing his "route" to make sure he has it down. Despite the crowd, there is no talking and little movement, save for the constant swirling of smoke from several cigars and cigarettes.  The group is like a theatre company waiting to go on opening night.

direction.raw_text: We follow him across the street and into the alley, where he signals one of the bodyguards to check the place out.  Kid Twist pushes a button on his window sill, and a buzzer goes off inside the store.  The previously inert figures there spring to life. Lonnegan's bodyguard descends the stairwell and knocks at the door, where he is greeted by Hooker in the capacity of host.  He looks the place over and motions an okay to Lonnegan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Lonnegan enters, we see the room for the first time in its entirety.  Overnight it has been transformed into a swank private club, with bar, cigarette girls, upholstered furniture and chandeliers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everywhere there is activity.  A bank of telephones buzzes incessantly.  Sheet writers scurry from phone to phone, taking bets of tremendous size from prominent people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We reveal that the phones are controlled by a master switch, which one of the recruited con men operates from behind a partition. The boardmaker, wearing headphones suspended from a sliding wire, hurriedly chalks up races and odds on a huge blackboard. From the loudspeakers we hear the words "last flash." The odds on Bluenote settle down to 8 to 1. Lonnegan makes his way through the throng toward the betting line.  His bodyguards fan out to various positions in the room.  The betting crowd itself (known as the "boost") consists of close to twenty people, none of whom, of course are what they're pretending to be.  There are brokers with pasty faces, sportsmen, tanned and casual, and financiers with goatees and highly tailored clothes.  Large amounts of money are changing hands at the betting window.  Boodles are in sight everywhere. Lonnegan slips into the betting line, feeling somewhat estranged from the general merriment around him.  There are two men in line ahead of him.  The first, Curly Jackson, slaps down several bundles of cash in front of Niles, who's the cashier, and places a $20,000 bet on War Eagle.  Gondorff appears at the cashier's window and catches sight of Lonnegan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man in front of Lonnegan puts $5,000 on Dancing Cloud. He makes the bet on credit.  Lonnegan steps to the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bluenote's race is now up on the board.  The race caller comes on the loudspeaker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see that the caller is Singleton, and that he's calling the race from a concealed booth next to the cashier's cage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan goes to the bar, orders a drink, and settles down at one of the tables.  It happens to be the one the Eirie Kid is at.  Gondorff and Niles watch it from the cashier's cage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eirie tries to ignore Lonnegan at first, but realizes he better make some conversation.

direction.raw_text: Eirie excuses himself and heads for the bar.

direction.raw_text: The heretofore chaotic energy of the parlor is now focused on the race.  Several of the patrons begin to yell for their horses.  Lonnegan remains seated.  He seems bored with it all.  Hooker comes over to clear some empty glasses from his table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan perks up just a little.  Bluenote, at least, has moved up.  The rest of the people in the place are really rooting now.  Few of them remain seated. Hooker arrives at the bar, with the glasses he cleared from Lonnegan's table.  Eirie is already there, fortifying himself with a scotch.

direction.raw_text: Eirie nods, somewhat unconvinced, and heads bak to the table.

direction.raw_text: The place is going crazy.  Even Singleton is standing up to get the necessary excitement in his voice.

direction.raw_text: Most of the patrons collapse into their chairs like spent lovers.  Eirie slams his racing form to the floor.  Nobody had Bluenote.

direction.raw_text: Eirie doesn't reply.  He can't believe Bluenote won. Lonnegan looks to Hooker.  Hooker gives him a wink.  For the first time, Lonnegan permits a smile.
