dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two-thousand on Bluenote.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (writing out a ticket) Is that all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pissed) That's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ladies and Gentlemen.  This is Arnold Rowe, your caller for the second race at Belmont in New York. A mile and 1/8.  Four year olds and up.  And they're off!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Around the first turn it's a War Eagle first by a length, Jail Bate second by one and a half, Dancing Cloud third by a half on the outside, followed by Lucky Lady, Mojo, Wits' End and Bluenote.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (worried) That's not where we want him to sit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon War Eagle. (to Lonnegan) That Dancing Cloud's a hell of a finisher.  War Eagle's gonna have to open up a little more on 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know anything about a horse named Bluenote?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naw, he's never done much.  Probably in here just to round out the field. War Eagle's where you wanna have your money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Into the clubhouse turn, it's War Eagle by two lengths, Dancing Cloud has moved up to second by a half, Lucky Lady is third by three followed by Jail Bait, Mojo, Bluenote and Wits' End.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (out of the corner of his mouth) You really picked a winner, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give 'em a little time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Into the backstretch it's War Eagle still by a length, Dancing Cloud closing on the inside, is second by two, Lucky Lady is third by one and a half, followed by Bluenote, Jail Bait, Wits' End and Mojo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're doin' great, Eirie.  He loves ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Into the far turn, it's Dancing Cloud now by half a length, War Eagle is second by two, Bluenote is third by a half and moving fast on the outside.  Lucky Lady is fourth by four lengths, followed by Jail Bait, Wits' End and Mojo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coming down the stretch, it's Dancing Cloud by one length, War Eagle and Bluenote are neck and neck by two.  Now it's Dancing Cloud, Bluenote and War Eagle. (shouting now) Dancing Cloud and Bluenote head to head...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dancing Cloud, Bluenote.  Dancing Cloud, Bluenote.  It's Bluenote by a nose.  Dancing Cloud is second by two, War Eagle third by three and a half.  Time for a mile and 1/8, 2:01 and 6/10 seconds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tearing up his ticket) Bloody awful.  Who in blazes is Bluenote?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Eirie, very self-satisfied) War Eagle's where you want to have your money, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Niles is counting out $16,000 to him (all of which Gondorff won the night before).  Gondorff looks somewhat perturbed. Lonnegan picks up the money and tauntingly waves it at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker hesitates a second.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff gives Hooker a hard shove in the back with his foot, sending him into a table and sprawling to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker, pretending to be humiliated, gets to his feet and escorts Lonnegan to the door.  Lonnegan stops, gives Gondorff a derisive smile, and walks out.  Once he's gone, the general clatter and hubbub in the room cease, like it had been turned off by a faucet.  Most of the boost sit down and relax.  Curly Jackson rips off his Van Dyke.  It's been itching him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (getting his name right this time) Don't bother to come back with a piker's bet like that again, Lonnegan.  We got a $5,000 minimum here. (to Hooker) Show this bum out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on, ya goddamn ninny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating Lonnegan's bodyguards) And tell him not to bring his garbage men in here no more.  This is a class joint.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's gaffed, kid.  He should start coming to you now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Combs sits passively on the edge of his desk glancing across the room every now and then at Riley, who is slumped uneasily in a folding chair, looking like a defendant at the Inquisition.  Both remain silent, like two men in a waiting room.  Suddenly, what they've been waiting for arrives. Lonnegan comes into the office, flanked by his bodyguards. Skipping the usual pleasantries, he walks right over to Riley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riley gets up and drags himself out the door like a whipped dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Combs gives up.  The second time's the charm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Combs keeps his mouth shut.  There's no way to talk to Lonnegan when  he's like this.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, Riley.  What the hell happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not looking at him) We missed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You weren't hired to miss him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There wasn't any way he coulda known we was in there.  We made a clean pick on the lock and didn't leave no footprints in the hall. Somebody musta wised him up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, and what does Cole say about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.  He took it hard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, get outa here.  You're outta work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll put Salino on it.  I need somebody careful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salino?  Why waste our best people on a small-time job like this?  It ain't no heavy gee we're after. The guy's a five and dime grifter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why ain't he dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They didn't think he'd be so cagey, that's all.  They'll get him next time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Use Salino.  It'll take a little longer, but there won't be any holes in it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And tell Cole I wanta see him when he gets in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not comin' in.  Not to get bounced off a job anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He had his chance and all he did was shoot up a rooming house.  Made a lotte noise and woke up a few cops, but didn't hit nothin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cooling a little) This is Salino's job now, Vince. If Cole wants to muscle in on it, that's his business.  But he's breakin' the rules and when Salino finds out about it, I can't feel sorry for what's gonna happen to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The finest the period had to offer.  We pick up Hooker coming down the hall to Lonnegan's suite.  He is admitted by the Bodyguard.  Lonnegan, wearing a smoking jacket, is seated at a table counting a pile of money.  There are two other assistants standing behind him.  They don't look friendly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan is amazed.  He sits back a second, then comes forward again and pushes a pile of bills over to Hooker. Hooker smiles and begins to count the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker's in a jam and he knows it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker says nothing for a minute, and then reluctantly nods his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what did I tell ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a lucky man, all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lucky, hell.  I could do it every day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't ya then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Cause it's better to do it all at once. (leaning close) We're puttin' down 400 grand next week.  At 5-1 we make 2 million. Twenty per cent of that is yours if ya stick with us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got a system, Carver?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You stayin' in or not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drawing up a chair, barely able to contain his enthusiasm) It's foolproof.  We got a partner downtown runs the central office of the Western Union.  Race results from all over the country come in there and go right across his desk on their way to the bookies.  All he does in hold them up a couple minutes until he can call us and get a bet down on the winner.  Then he releases the results to the bookies and we clean up on a race that's already been run.  It can't miss, unless the Western Union Dicks get onto it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got the 400 grand yet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet, but... (stopping suddenly) Hey, there's only a grand here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (more like a command) I think we oughta place another bet tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting angry) What is this?  That's my money. You tryin' to muscle me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (controlled) If your system's as foolproof as you say, you'll get even more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) I gotta talk to me partner first. We can't afford to expose our game too much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me talk to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flatly) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want your money back?  Try and get it in a court of law. (softening a bit) C'mon, don't be a sorehead.  I'll make it worth your while.  Migth even help ya finance the big play if this one works out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four o'clock tomorrow.  Pick me up at Dewey Lyle's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We pick up Hooker coming out of the hotel and going off down the street.  As he does so, we pull back all the way across the street and through the interior of a parked car to reveal the silhouette of a man seated at the wheel.  We move to his right hand, which rests on the steering column.  It's covered by a black glove and the middle finger is missing. His trigger finger, however, taps lightly on the wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the old, wooden kind -- accordian doors with glass panes in the upper half.  Hooker dials rapidly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker blows a mock kiss through the phone and hangs up.  He turns to leave the booth, when suddenly he sees something that stops him cold.  There looking through the glass is the smirking face of Detective Synder.  Hooker is immobilized. Snyder puts his hand inside his coat and slowly draws out his gun.  He points it right at Hooker's face and then violently smashes all the glass in the upper half of the door with the barrel.  Fragments of glass spray into the booth, a couple of which imbed themselves in Hooker's cheek. Hooker quickly whips open the door, trapping Snyder's hand in the accordian and jarring loose his gun.  Hooker sprints out of the booth as Snyder scrambles for his pistol and gives pursuit.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Twist?  I told him the tale.  He wants to see ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, when?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow, after 4:00.  Stay inside, I'll come in and get ya.  And be hard on him for a while; he's talking money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Tootsie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - THE TWO MEN We follow the two men up alleys and sidestreets as they race through the dregs of the city, two panting shadows moving through places that only get light at night.  The wind blows drops of blood off Hooker's cheek as he runs.  Snyder still has his gun, but would rather inflict pain than death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker makes for a condemned building and scrambles up the stairs, steps giving way under him as he goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the fourth floor, he ducks into a room and quickly locks the door. We pan the room to reveal that the whole back side of the building is gone.  Hooker runs toward the ledge and leaps through the air, landing on the fire escape of an adjacent building, some 15 feet away.  He kicks in a window and goes off down the hall.  We cut back to Snyder furiously kicking in the locked door.  He finally crashes through, only to find an empty room and a beautiful panorama of the city and its nearest Hooverville.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winding his way through the slum area of town, dashing along backstreets, over fences and through vacant lots, making good his escape.  From our angle, he looks like a rat in a maze.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Why didn't you tell me about Snyder before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I thought I'd lost him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hooker sits sullenly at the table.  Billie stands over him putting some ointment on his face to close the cuts. Gondorff looks on.  Their discussion continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker doesn't reply.  He knows Gondorff's on to him.
direction.name: direction

location: GONDORFF'S ROOM AT THE CAROUSEL BUILDING
result.heading: INT.

dialogue.raw_text: Well you found him again and we're gonna have to do somethin' about it. What else haven't ya been tellin' me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothin'.  I told ya everything there is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why'd ya move outa your room?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was too noisy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't play your friends like marks, Hooker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know how easy it'd be for one of Lonnegan's guys to nail you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All we need is a couple days, Henry. A couple days and we'll get Lonnegan down and stomp on 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just won't learn, will ya. Hell, you come in here, I teach you stuff maybe five guys in this world know, stuff most grifters couldn't do even if they knew it, and all you wanna do is run down a bullet. (pause) You're just like all them new jerks. Lotsa nerve and no brains.  And ten years from now when me and the others are through and you dumb guys are all dead there won't be one gee left who knows the Big Con was anything more than a way to make a livin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A couple days; that's all I'm askin'.  I can stay clear that long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to be angry and failing) Christ, they'll probably miss you and hit me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Located across the street from Hooker's apartment building. Hooker sits down alone in a booth, with a plate of ham and eggs he's hardly touched. The two cuts on his face have pretty much stopped bleeding. A big fan above the counter area drones away lethargically, it's air stream insufficient to either cool the place or drive out the smell of onions and grease. A waitress, Loretta, emerges from the kitchen and ambles slowly over to Hooker's table.  Slim and raven-haired, she manifests an indifference bred from years spent delivering things to people who are rarely grateful for what she brings. Only a light scar on her left cheek hints at another side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker looks for some sign that she's putting him on.  He doesn't get it.  He takes out some money, drops it on the table and walks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You done?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, I guess I shoulda had the meat loaf.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (deadpan) It isn't any better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's June today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (figuring up the bill) She don't work here no more.  I'm fillin' in for a couple days... till I can get a train outa here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where you goin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting the check down and walking away) I don't know.  Depends what train I get on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A truck with the words CLAYTON BROS., CUSTOM PAINTING AND DECORATING stenciled on the side, is parked out front.  Two men, wearing overalls and painter's caps, walk into the office to the reception counter, we see that they are Twist and Singleton.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the receptionist) Excuse me.  We're here to paint Mr. Harmon's office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (obviously not expecting them) Mr. Harmon's office?  Hold on just a second. She goes to get Mr. Harmon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hooker is standing on the curb outside the diner, obviously waiting for somebody.  Lonnegan's car pulls up and Hooker hops in the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan laughs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What happened to your face?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Had a little fight with a raggle down on 13th.  She got me with her ring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mr. Harmon is looking over the authorization papers that Twist and Singleton have given him.  He can't find anything wrong with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harmon looks around, hoping it's not true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harmon is resigned.  Twist and Singleton pick up their gear and march into the office.  Once inside, we notice that the office has an exit door which opens to an outside alley. Twist immediately removes his overalls, revealing the suit and tie he's wearing underneath.  He takes out a picture of himself, a woman and three small children, and puts it on Harmon's desk, replacing a similiar picture of Harmon's family.  Singleton, meanwhile, has spread a few tarps and begins to paint the walls.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Brigham signed it all right.  I can't understand why he didn't tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, he's like all them supervisors. They think they're too good for regular people.  He says he was in here a while ago and the place was a mess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll try and hurry so we don't keep you out of your office too long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why can't I work with you in there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look pal, we gotta cover the floor, the furniture, everything, so we don't spill on nothing.  Now if you wanta sit in there with a tarp over your head, you're welcome to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, how long will you be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hour or two at the most.  We do good work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan's car pulls up and stops across the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We follow Hooker and Lonnegan across the street to the side entrance which opens into:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We'll go to the side door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hooker knocks and Twist, of course, answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twist walks over to the intercom on his desk.  He leaves the door open so that Lonnegan can get a good look at the office, Twist's picture in it, the painter, etc... Lonnegan's not missing any of it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Les, I got Mr. Lonnegan with me. He wants to see you a second.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated) What the hell's the matter with you. We coulda met at a club or somethin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought it might be good for him to see the setup.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hushed) Well we can't talk in here.  They're having the place painted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (talking into the intercom) Miss Barnes, I'm going home a little early today.  Tell anyone that calls that they can reach me here in the morning.  Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Harmon's secretary at the other end of the intercom.  Mr. Harmon is with her.  They look at each other a second and Harmon decides he better see what's happening in his office. He opens the door to find it empty except for a pile of painting equipment and one haphazardly painted wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dark and somewhat foreboding, its peeling dragons and shoddy lanterns compete for space with the many slot machines and arcade games that line the walls.  Hooker, Lonnegan and Twist sit at one of the more secluded tables.  They are not eating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twist hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twist says nothing for a minute, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker and Lonnegan smile at each other like life-long friends.  They get up to leave, and we frame the shot with a coffee cup large in the foreground.  As they go out the door, a black-gloved hand with four fingers enters the frame and puts a nickel down next to the cup.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can't do it.  There're telegraph inspectors all over the place.  I got 750 grand coming in from the coast, and I'm not gonna blow it for a lousy 14 gees.  We'll get somebody else to do our betting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could come up with 750 grand in a day if I had a reason to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But who says you will.  I got a guy I can depend on.  He's liquidating everything he has for this.  You wouldn't even give Carver his money back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need more proof, that's all. Anybody can get lucky once.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stubbornly) On a 6-1 shot?  The hell with ya. We'll keep the deal we got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If it works again tomorrow, I'll have a half million in cash here by noon the next day.  We split 60-40.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (feebly, beginning to break) We were getting 50 from our guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With 20% coming off the top for me laying your bet.  Either way you end up with 40.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A week's a long time, friend. Anything can happen.  All of it bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's right, Les.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, and what if we play tomorrow and he doesn't come up with the money.  We risk our whole operation for nothing.  I'll say when we make our bets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not if you want me to keep makin' 'em for ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what do we know about your guy. He says a week, but who knows if it's a month?  Lonnegan here's a banker.  He can get that dough with no questions asked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right.  Be at the booth at 1:00. I'll give you all three places this time, Lonnegan.  That better be proof enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Snyder finishes a donut and a cup of coffee, puts down a dime for the lot and exits.  We follow him down the street:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To a corner newsstand, where he stops to buy a morning paper. As he peruses it, he's approached by two large, clean-cut men in white skimmers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two men show him to a waiting car.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you Lieutenant William Snyder?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, what's up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: .B.I... The Captain'd like a few words with ya.  Ya got a couple minutes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (completely floored) Yeh, sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Snyder stands in the middle of a dusty old machine room, surrounded by four or five Federal Agents.  Visible around the room are several folding cots and portable lockers.  The agents have obviously been quartered here temporarily.  They all wear white skimmers, save for one, a portly man, Captain Polk, who paces the room smoking.  There is something long- suffering about him, as if he wondered how he ever got in a service that thought white skimmers were classy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snyder doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is this?  I got work to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit down and shut up, will ya.  Try not to live up to all my expectations. (not in the mood to screw around) We were told you know a hustle artist named Johnny Hooker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do ya know him or don't ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, but I don't know where he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well we do.  He's chummin' around with a Big C named Henry Gondorff. Ring any bells?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.  Every bunco man in the country knows Gondorff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's word he's gonna run a con on the North Side here.  We got a year-old Florida warrant on him, but it's a thin beef, and he can beat it in court unless we catch him cold.  All we want you to do is pick up Hooker for us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you pick him up yourself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cause the stoolies are used to street dicks jumpin' him.  If word gets around that Feds are in on it too, Gondorff'll fold up the whole thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wouldn't that be too bad.  You'd hafta move outa this nice office ya got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (enraged) Don't crack wise to me, flatfoot. I spent a lotta time in dumps like this, eatin' Gondorff's dust while the bunco squad gets rich tippin' him off.  But it's not gonna happen this time.  We're not even gonna let the police know we're here.  If you keep your mouth shut and do a job, there'll be a promotion in it for ya.  And you better take it, cause I can make ya work for us without it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell good is Hooker to ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's gonna set up Gondorff for us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'll never do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (self-satisfied) I think he will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan sits by the phone, watching the clock and sipping a cup of coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Specifically, the small room from which Singleton does his race broadcasts.  Singleton, himself, is hunched over the ticker machine, reading the print-out.  Billie sits at the microphone table with a pencil and pad, ready to write.
direction.name: direction

He's talking to Niles, who's busy handing out fake bankrolls to members of the boost.

He finishes his meal and comes down to the register to pay his bill.

location: SLEEZY DINER ACROSS FROM HOOKER'S APT

dialogue.raw_text: Meat loaf, apple pie and a cup of coffee.

direction.raw_text: Hooker goes to the front door and steps outside.  Cole looks up at the sound of the door.  Hooker makes a big show of spotting him, and runs back into the diner.  Cole, his cover blown, draws his gun and races across the street in pursuit. Arriving just in time to see -- INT. DINER Hooker go into the bathroom, he charges in after him, only to find the place empty.  He goes quickly from stall to stall, on the chance that Hooker might be hiding in one of them. He comes to one that's closed, and seeing a pair of woman's legs under the door, rejects that, and moves on to the next one. We cut inside the stall to reveal Loretta sitting on the toilet with her skirt hiked up.  Right behind her, crouched on the back of the seat, is Hooker. Cole has finished his rapid inspection now, and having found nothing, looks around for Hooker's probable escape route. He sees the open window and climbs out to find himself in a small air shaft, from which he knows Hooker could not escape. Hooker, seizing the time, bursts out of the stall and runs back out through the diner.  Cole sees him, but too late to get off a shot.  He climbs back in the window and gives chase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We pick up Hooker barreling down the street with Cole a hundred yards or so behind.  Hooker makes a sharp cut into an alley, and we see immediately that it's a hopeless dead end.  Inexplicably, he makes no attempt to run back out. Cole draws up and cuts into the alley, anticipating the kill which should be easy now.  He prepares to sight down his victim, when suddenly he realizes there is no victim in sight.  Hooker, miraculously, has vanished.  Cole scans the alley frantically for some trace of him.  There are no windows or doors at the street level.  Not even a drain pipe. Just brick wall.  It's impossible.  Hooker has disappeared into thin air. Cole slams his gun into his shoulder holster with a curse, and starts back out of the alley, when all of a sudden he stops in utter terror.  His mouth drops open and he chokes out the words:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before anything else can come out, two bullets rip into his chest.  He falls to the concrete, coming to rest on a manhole cover, which we notice is slightly ajar.  We:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Salino, hey look.  I didn't mean to move in on...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Beneath the manhole.  We see Hooker making his way through the slop, having gained another reprieve, but unaware that with two down, there is still one to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker comes in the front entrance and goes to the elevator, one of the old-fashioned kind with the iron grid on the inside.  He's still a little rattled and waiting for the elevator is making him restless.  It finally arrives, and he steps inside, closing the grid behind him.  As he starts to push the button for his floor, he realizes for the first time that he's not alone.  He looks to the corner to find Snyder, holding a gun on him.  This time there's not much doubt that he'll use it if necessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker wants to come back with something, but can't find it.

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Mr. Hooker.  Captain Polk, F.B.I... (shoving a chair over to him) Have a seat.

dialogue.raw_text: (ignoring it, drinking from a cup) You want a drink or something?

dialogue.raw_text: No.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't think I know him.

dialogue.raw_text: Well give yourself a couple seconds, crumb.  You wouldn't wanna lie to me.  Lt. Snyder here says you done a lotta griftin' in this town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lt. Snyder doesn't know shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got nothin' on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll get it, and if we can't, we'll just make it up.  Grand larceny, extortion. (with special emphasis) Counterfeiting, anything you want.

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I got nothin' against you, but you're in trouble here.  All you gotta do is tell us when Gondorff's gonna play his chump. We come in at the sting, make the pinch, and you walk out free as a bird.  No questions, no court appearance, nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've already done time twice, and judges don't like three time losers. You wanna sit in the can for forty years, startin' tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll make parole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like hell.  You won't even get a review till you're seventy.  And if the board starts to go soft, we'll let ya out in the yard some night with a hard-nose young bull who'll put fifty slugs in your face and ask what you were doin' there later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be a sap, kid.  You could save us a little trouble.  But Henry Gondorff is through whether you help us or not.  There's nothin' left to do now but save yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Will you wait until the chump is played?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell yes.  We don't care about the mark.  He deserves what he gets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with heat) I mean completely played.  Until he's beat and the score is taken. You come in before we beat him and I'll kill him.  You'll have a tough time explaining that, won't ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, Hooker, but you take it on the lam, and we'll shoot you down on sight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (barely audible) Just as long as I get to finish the play.

direction.raw_text: Gondorff and Hooker are playing gin rummy and drinking. Gondorff makes little comments as he plays, but Hooker is quiet and withdrawn.  The carousel is not in operation and a heavy silence hangs over the place.

direction.raw_text: Hooker smiles feebly. Billie appears at the door.

direction.raw_text: Gondorff takes out a set of keys and tosses them to her. She leaves to go start the merry-go-round.  Gondorff settles back into the game.

direction.raw_text: That's good enough.  Hooker gets up to leave.

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter, kid?  You're not sayin' much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a little nervous, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Luther always told me to bite my toenails when I get nervous.  You see yourself doin' that and you realize it ain't worth it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Things are a little slow tonight, Henry.  I wanna open the round for the girls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take it easy, you won't lose him now.  We had him 10 years ago when he decided to be somebody.  Believe me, I've seen enough to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) How many guys you conned in your life, Henry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two or three hundred I guess. Sometimes played two a day when I was in Shea's mob.  We had it down to a business. (pause) 'Course Chicago was a right town then.  The fix was in.  The dicks took their end without a beef.  All the Wall Street boys wanted to make investments for us.  Even had marks looking us up, thinkin' they could beat the game. (pause) Yeh, kid, it really stunk.  No sense in bein' a grifter if it's the same as bein' a citizen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I better do some packin'.  I'm gonna be a hot number again after tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why you doin' it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seems worthwhile, doesn't it? Maybe it's just for the cave-in on Lonnegan's face when we put in the sting.

dialogue.raw_text: Henry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (apologetically) I appreciate your stickin' your neck out.  I wouldn't have asked ya if it weren't for Luther.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ain't nothin' gonna make up for Luther, kid. (pause) Revenge is for suckers.  I been griftin' 30 years and never got any.

direction.raw_text: We follow him past the Carousel which is now full of giggling prostitutes in various stages of undress.  Their childish frolicking is charming from a group usually so jaded, but it's lost on Hooker tonight.

direction.raw_text: It's late now and the street is deserted save for an occasional derelict or streetwalker on her way home from a night's work.  We pick up Hooker coming down the street toward his apartment building.  He walks slowly, almost reluctantly, as if he didn't care whether he ever got there or not. As he nears his building, he notices Loretta coming out of the diner across the street.  He stops and watches as she looks up and disappears into an adjacent building that advertises rooms for rent.  After a few seconds, we see a light come on in one of its second story windows. Hooker just stands there a second, debating with himself, trying to figure out a reason for doing what he's going to do anyway.  We follow him across the street to Loretta's building and:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes up the stairs to the room where the light came on. He passes a couple of derelicts on the way.  He knocks twice and Loretta answers in her bathrobe.  She is more than a little startled to see him.

direction.raw_text: Loretta notices an old busybody peeping out at them from her room across the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Hillard quickly closes her door.

direction.raw_text: Loretta looks at him carefully.  She knows it's not a line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two just stand there in silence a second.  There's nothing more to say.  She stands back and lets him in.

dialogue.raw_text: (shuffling a little)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ah...thought you might wanna come out for a while.  Maybe have a drink or somethin'.

dialogue.raw_text: You move right along, don't ya.

dialogue.raw_text: (with more innocence than confidence) I don't mean nothin' by it.  I just don't know many regular girls, that's all.

direction.raw_text: A record spinning lazily on an old phonograph.  We hear Robert Johnson's "Come On In My Kitchen." Gondorff is sitting up in bed, with his hat on, lost in thought.  Billie is curled up asleep next to him.  There's a packed suitcase next to the bed.  Billie wakes up and turns over a second.

direction.raw_text: Gondorff nods his agreement like a zombie and goes right on thinking.

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, Henry, knock off.  You've done everything you can.

direction.raw_text: Hooker and Loretta are asleep against each other, their bodies illuminated every few seconds by the light from a neon sign across the street.  We dolly to the window and move in on another window in the building next door.  There's no light on in it, but we can discern the basic outline of a face behind the curtains, which are slightly parted to afford a view of Hooker's room by a black-gloved hand.

dialogue.raw_text: said come on in my kitchen Cause it's gonna be rainin' outdoors."

direction.raw_text: : We open on Hooker in bed, the morning sun streaming in on his face.  He awakens slowly, looks at the ceiling for a second and, remembering last night, turns to the side to find that Loretta is no longer there.  Still drowsy, he gets out of bed and looks around the room for a note or some evidence of her continued presence.  He opens an empty closet, then opens empty drawers.  Finding nothing, he suddenly hits on another possibility, and looks in his wallet.  The money is still there.  Almost disappointed, he slumps down in a chair, as the harsh reality of what will happen this day floods back in on him.  Music begins and we:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the black-gloved hand opening a small wooden box. Wrapped inside is a shiny black revolver, at this point in two pieces.  The hand reaches in and takes them out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker is poking at a plate of waffles and sausage.  The waitress on duty is not Loretta and Hooker has noticed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff is standing in front of the bathroom mirror, putting on his tuxedo.  He goes to his dresser, pulls out a very small gun and tucks it in his cummerbund.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hand swirls a pipe cleaner inside the barrel of the revolver and picks some lint out of the chamber.  He then screws the barrel onto the body.  This is all seen in closeup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker now has his tuxedo on.  He takes two small rubber bladders out of a drawer and puts them in his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan paces nervously around the room, looking at the clock.  Obviously waiting for something, he's getting extremely impatient.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We watch the hand carefully loading bullets into the chamber of the revolver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff emerges from his room carrying his suitcase.  He stops and looks up at the mezzanine where Billie is standing. They smile sadly at each other and give a simple wave, having done this too many times to get sentimental about it now.  Gondorff walks out of the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker is busily stuffing all his possessions in a paper bag, lumping clothes with food, records and toilet articles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan goes to the door to admit Floyd and two assistants, one of whom carries a large brief case.  Lonnegan takes the brief case to a table and opens it.  Inside is a half million dollars in cash.

direction.raw_text: We see the hand putting a silencer on the revolver.  The gunman puts the revolver up to his eye to check the alignment and for the first time we see the face that goes with the hand.  It is fully as menacing as we had imagined: Broad, flat nose, thick cracked lips, narrow eyes and cauliflower ears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker is on the phone now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see that he's talking to Captain Polk.  Snyder listens also.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker finishes the conversation, hangs up and goes to take one last look at himself in the mirror.  Finding everything in order, he grabs up his sack of possessions and leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We pick him up emerging from the building, and follow him around the corner to a secluded alley which he generally takes on his way to the store.  As he walks along, he notices Loretta coming toward him from the other end.  She's wearing a coat, obviously on her way somewhere.  As she comes closer, we move to reveal the gunman appearing suddenly in the alley behind and to the right of Hooker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gunman quickly takes out his revolver, braces it in the crook of his hand, and takes careful aim.  Loretta sees him. The gunman fires.  Loretta falls dead on the asphalt. Hooker spins around in confusion.  The gunman moves quickly toward him.  Hooker starts to back up but the gunman stops when he gets to Loretta.  He kicks her over to reveal a gun under her body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker is stunned.  He can't believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker wants to stay and try to figure it all out, but the gunman drags him away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She was gonna kill ya, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dragging the body over behind a trash can) Her name's Loretta Salino. Lonnegan's people set her up in the diner.  C'mon, let's get outa here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Polk, Snyder and several federal agents are busy putting on their shoulder holsters, and checking their weapons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snyder nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Snyder) Whoever Gondorff's playin' for is bound to be a wheel.  As soon as we're inside, I want you to get the guy outa there as fast as possible, before the reporters show up.  We can't afford to embarrass any big shots.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan, carrying the brief case personally, is seen getting into his limousine.  Four assistants get in with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff enters the store carrying his suitcase.  Several of the boost are already there.  Gondorff clasps his hands to generate a little enthusiasm.  He's obviously up for this one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker sits in the back seat with the gunman right next to him.  He's still very uneasy with this man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We go to Hooker.  No, he doesn't.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She coulda killed me last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too many people coulda seen ya go in her room.  She was a professional. Used to work in the Dutch Schultz gang.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gondorff asked me to look after ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do I know you're tellin' the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't have much choice, do ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We pick up Polk, Snyder and the other federal agents coming out of the warehouse in their white skimmers, and piling into cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Niles is busily spreading "boodles" all over the cashier's area.  Singleton checks his microphone.  It works fine.  He checks it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds the brief case in his lap, his fingers tapping lightly on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker and the gunman enter and go over to Gondorff, who breaks into a wide smile.  Hooker returns it halfheartedly, still ill at ease about what has happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .B.I. CARS ON THEIR WAY There are four or five driving in a column.  Snyder and Polk ride together in the back of the lead car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan's limousine pulls up outside, and the bodyguards pile out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff, Hooker and the others waiting, the tension expressed in their faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan sits tensely in the usual booth.  He keeps both hands firmly planted on the brief case.  The phone rings and Lonnegan goes to it.  Music ends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan hangs up with the look of the financial killer. Eight to one odds is more than even he could have hoped for.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Place it on Syphon at 8-1.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We follow Lonnegan across the street and into the store. The bodyguards remain outside. INT. THE STORE The store is buzzing with activity.  Money and booze are everywhere.  The sheet writer and the boardmarker can hardly keep up with the action.  Lonnegan walks quickly to the betting line and finds to his relief that there's only one man ahead of him.  The man puts $25,000 on King's Image. Lonnegan steps to the window, swings up the brief case, and opens it for Niles to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Niles is struck dumb.  He's never seen that much money before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Niles goes and returns with Gondorff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff looks at the money a second and then looks up at Lonnegan like he's gotta be crazy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff looks at Lonnegan long and hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The words "Last Flash" are heard on the speaker.  Gondorff looks at Lonnegan with utter contempt.  He turns to Niles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Niles hurriedly writes out a slip for 500,000 dollars. Lonnegan, allowing himself a sly smile, picks it up and retires to a nearby table.  He flashes a little okay sign to Hooker who acknowledges it with a nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan takes a deep breath and leans forward in his chair, the larceny boiling in his veins.  Hooker looks to Gondorff. Gondorff gives him the "office." Hooker has to smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unexpectedly, Kid Twist bursts in through the entrance. Barely able to control his enthusiasm, he hurries over to Lonnegan's table and sits down next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan looks like he's just been stabbed.  He vaults over the table to the teller's window and grabs Niles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lonnegan begins to shake him violently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff leaps to Niles' aid when suddenly there is a crash at the entrance door, and Polk, Snyder and eight federal agents burst into the room, guns drawn.  The place falls silent except for the loudspeaker, the members of the boost afraid to move.  Gondorff and Niles look at each other wondering how this could have possibly happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker's eyes go to Gondorff, who looks back at him in utter disbelief, the betrayal raging in his features.  Hooker, unable to meet his gaze, lowers his head and starts to walk out.  Almost unnoticed, there's a flash of movement at Gondorff's belt.  A small gun.  A shot.  Hooker clutches his back and falls dead on the floor, the blood spurting from his mouth.  Polk, reacting instantly, pours four shots into Gondorff, who goes down in a heap.  Pandemonium breaks loose. The members of the boost race for the door.  Lonnegan is totally stunned.  First he lost his money and now he's involved in a murder.  Snyder rushes over to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (straight-faced) Five hundred grand on Syphon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (playing the flustered clerk) Hold on, I'll have to get the manager.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the problem?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing to the brief case) He wants to put a half million on Syphon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uneasily) I can't lay that off in time.  We lose a bet that big, it could break us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (challenging) If ya win it could make ya, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Niles) What are the odds on Syphon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eight to one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A half mill on an eight to one shot. You're dumber than I thought, Lonnegan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're more gutless than I thought.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (chopped) Take it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ladies and gentlemen, this is Arnold Rowe, your caller for the San Antonio Handicap at Pimlico in Baltimore -- A mile and 1/16 for three-year-olds.  And they're off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And around the first turn it's King's Image by a neck, Syphon is second by one, Key to the Vault third by one half, followed by Mr. Moonlight, Red Ridge, Moneyman and No Charge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, but I just couldn't wait. Did everything go all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (motioning for him to keep his voice down) Take it easy.  Everything's all right.  I put it on Syphon, on the nose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in utter horror) On the nose!  I said place.  Place it on Syphon.  That horse is going to run second.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You give me my goddamn money back! You hear me?  There's been a mistake!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, sir.  The betting's closed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You give me my money back.  There's been a mistake, do you hear me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (motioning to Hooker) All right, Hooker, you can go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon.  We gotta get you outa here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Snyder drags him through the crowd and out onto the street where an F.B.I. car is waiting.  His bodyguards have long since fled at the sight of the F.B.I. men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snyder gets in beside Lonnegan, and the car speeds away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: My money's back there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll worry about that later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The pandemonium has now ceased.  Those who could escape have; the rest are lined up against the wall in frisking position.  Gondorff and Hooker lie on the floor dead.  The loudspeaker drones on.  Singleton is still calling the race from his booth, apparently oblivious to what's happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Polk walks slowly over to Hooker's body and bends down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooker opens his eyes and slowly drags himself up off the floor, spitting out a little rubber bladder, filled with blood, that he's had in his mouth.  Gondorff does likewise. Niles, Twist, Singleton and the rest of the boost begin to laugh and shake hands, as do the Federal Agents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff turns to the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff walks over to Hooker, who's wiping the blood off his face and hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gondorff nods, and walks slowly to behind the bar.  He comes out with his suitcase in one hand and Hooker's paper bag in another.  He throws the paper bag to Hooker, who stops by the door.  Eirie Kid is standing there.  Hooker gives the "office" to Eirie, who beams and gives it back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And the winner is King's Image by four lengths, Syphon is second, by two, Moneyman third by two and one half.  Time for 1 and 1/16 miles,
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: :21 and 2/10 seconds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Polk) Nice con, Hickey.  I thought you were Feds myself, when you first came in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No problem, Henry.  Snyder went for it all the way. (laughing) You shoulda seen the rag he lit under Lonnegan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, let's take this place apart and get outa here.  You can get your splits from Eddie at Boudreau's tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You beat him, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) You were right, Henry.  It's not enough... But it's close.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wanta wait for your share?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naw, I'd just blow it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Then Hooker and Gondorff leave.  We hold on them, two ragtail grifters again as they walk off down the street and disappear around the corner.
direction.name: direction
